title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: Therefore Middlemass was declaredsole heir to the enormous property. Changing his name to Barnton, permission wasobtained for his being declared heir to thebaronetcy which the old banker had extorted from the Dundas famUy as interestfor some money lent to them.

title: The World According to Bertie
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: While Bruce was entertaining Julia in her flat in Howe Street, Big Lou was busy with one of her periodic cleanings of the coffee house in Dundas Street. It was a Saturday, and Saturdays were always quieter than weekdays, with many of the usual customers – office people – at home in places such as Barnton or Corstorphine, contemplating their gardens or their dirty cars and resolving to do something about both of them, but perhaps tomorrow rather than today. Dundas Street itself was reasonably busy, but for some reason many of the people in the street had things other than coffee on their minds, and this left Big Lou the time to do her cleaning.

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: Matters remained, therefore, in statu quofor some months—Lady Barnton havingnearly forgotten all such causes of disquietude in the luxuries and frivolities offashionable dissipation which her naturaltaste and large income so well enabled herto gratify.

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Scones
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: There had been, he suspected, little passion in his life, and relatively few disappointments. He had lived in Barnton, a comfortable suburb in which nothing of note happened, and

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: Brodie having failed in getting the legalheir to come into court and claim the property,turned about in search of another one, andfixed upon a person of the name of Middlemass, who was descended from one of thefemales of the Barnton fanhly, as his nextbest card to play. He got the right personthis time.

snippet: He couldscarce see Marv this time; but he felt itall. She had again young Barnton for herescort; and he heard the parting words ashe said good night.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Dined at Sir John Hay's with Ramsay of Barnton and his young bride. Sir David and Lady Hunter Blair, etc.

title: Romances of the old town of Edinburgh /
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: The one bore the name of William Halket, a young man, who, eight or nine years before he became of much interest either to himself or any other body, was what in our day is called an Arab of the City — a poor street boy, who didn't know who his father was, though, as for his mother, he knew her by a pretty sharp experience, insomuch as she took from him every penny he made by holding horses, and gave him more cuffs than cakes in return. But Bill got out of this bondage by the mere chance of having been taken a fancy to by Mr Peter Ramsay, innkeeper and stabler, in St Mary's Wynd, (an ancestor, we suspect, of the Ram says of Barnton,) who thought he saw in the City Arab that love of horse-flesh which belongs to the Bedouin, and who accordingly elevated him to the position of a stable-boy, with board and as many shillings a week as there are days in that subdivision of time.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: "You have been a fortunate man, my Lord President. Barnton is a singular fine estate."

snippet: All, all is lost! The dice on whichI left my last chance has lost me the game,and I no longer aspire to win your hand. Let young Barnton have it. Let yourworldly father barter it to whom he hkes ;it is nothing to me now, Mary.

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: Liddell thought this a golden opportunityfor putting his scheme into force. Inflamedagainst young Barnton as Constantine nodoubt was, because he fancied him a rival,and burning with vexation for his want ofrank, fame, or wealth, which operated as abarrier to his love—now was the time togain him over to his cause. Yes, now ornever!

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: The young baronet had never yet seenthe artist; but hearing Lady Mary's exclamation, he knew at once the extraordinary-looking personage now before him. But Barnton was greatly excited on seeinghow like he was to a miniature he had seenin his mother's possession, and could nothelp feehng that he should know the remarkable face.

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: Lady Mary Belmont, therefore, on thepresent occasion, was the centre of a perfect net-work of intrigue, and had in turnto endure the concentrated machinations ofthe three mammas—Lady Barnton for herson, Lady Ravelstone for her brother, andLady Bruntsfield for her protSge. But theyoung lady was the best possible rock forsuch opposite waves to break upon.
